Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Evolution of the deep South Atlantic since the last interglacial period inferred from a depth transect of Cape Basin sediment cores
Award.AbstractNarration:
There is considerable evidence that the deep ocean plays some role in governing the evolution of Pleistocene ice ages and interglacial periods. Yet after several decades of research, there is still debate over the degree to which sedimentary tracers can distinguish differences in deep ocean circulation between ice age oceans and the modern ocean. This collaborative project will investigate past ocean circulation changes by generating multi-proxy records for several common paleoceanographic tracers (including benthic d18O and d13C, radiocarbon, Cd/Ca, Zn/Ca and B/Ca) for eight time slices over the last glacial-interglacial cycle using cores along a depth transect from the Namibian margin and Cape Basin. These time slices would represent the step in evolution from interglacial state through a full glacial cycle. The research will focus around a series of questions concerning water mass evolution in the Atlantic Ocean, the connection between circulation and carbon cycling, differences between conservative and non-conservative proxies, and the possibility for major boundary condition changes distinct from ocean mixing effects.

Broader impacts:
This project will provide a detailed picture of the mixing between the two principal deep water masses of the world's ocean across a full ice cycle, which will be of widespread use to oceanographers and climate scientists. Funding will support two Ph.D. students and provide significant experience in proxy data collection and interpretation. The project will also serve as a platform for a summer REU fellow and provide support for several undergraduate students to learn research and laboratory techniques. Additionally, funding will help develop a lesson on deep earth circulation through the Deep Earth Academy at Texas A&M University.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit: Vertically spaced profiles of seawater properties--for example, "conductivity-temperature-depth" (CTD) casts--remain the standard means for describing the chemistry and circulation of the modern deep ocean. Extending such descriptions to the past ocean generally relies on sampling sediment cores in regions where the seafloor intersects a range of water depths and watermasses in a limited geographical area. Previous evidence demonstrated that the ice age deep ocean was almost everywhere near its freezing point and that the deep ocean was stratified by salt, as opposed to temperature (unlike the modern ocean. ) Various models of the carbon cycle suggest that this change in the structure of the deep ocean should have a profound effect on the storage of carbon in the deep ocean (and hence its removal from the atmosphere). By documenting the evolution of deep ocean properties in a depth transect of sediment cores, we aimed to determine exactly when the change occurred from a warm temperature-stratified deep ocean (characteristic of interglacial periods) to the cold, salinity stratified ocean (characteristic of ice ages). By comparing physical tracers in the sediments (that might resolve temperature and saliinty) with coeval tracers for the carbon cycle, we aimed to elucidate how the structural changes in the deep ocean affected its capacity to store carbon.

Accordlingly, In this project we have constructed a "depth transect" of sediment cores from the Namibian margin that span a water depth range of 1300-4200 meters, featuring sedimentary sequences that accumulated over the last full ice age cycle (roughly the last 150,000 years). We reconstructed vertical profiles of deep ocean properties--as captured in "proxy" form by the chemistry of calcium carbonate tests of benthic foraminifera--at critical junctures of the last ice age cycle. Upon construction, these vertical profiles were rigorously controlled for quality in a number of ways: we ensured that all samples in any given vertical profile were equivalent in age (within +/- 1 kyr); we limited our analyses to the exact same morphotype of benthic foraminifer; and we conducted all analyses in the same two laboratories, thus limiting the possibility for interlab differences. Consequently, our results constitute as yet one of the cleanest documentations for the ice age evolution of deep Atlantic properties.

The results from the physical tracers (specifically: oxygen isotopic composition which is a proxy for density; and Mg/Ca, which correlates to temperature) suggest the while the temperature structure of the interior ocean during the last interglacial period (125 ka) was similar to that of the present ocean, the deep Atlantic ocean cooled dramatically 10 kyr later (at ~115 ka) to near ice age temperatures. On the other hand, the onset of saliniity stratification (as deduced from the comparison between oxygen isotopes and Mg/Ca) apparently did not occur untill ~70 ka. The magntude and timing of the changes we observe point strongly to changes in the mechanisms of deep water formation in both poles--as opposed to merely the rate of formation or mixing--and were most likely driven by changes in the seasonal receipt of solar radiation.

Meanwhile, the tracers for carbon chemistry (specifically: carbon isotopic composition, which mirrors total dissolved carbon; and B/Ca which is correlatesd to carbonate ion composition) confirm that enhanced storage of carbon at depth accompanied the switch to a cold salinity-stratified state.  During ice age intervals, the vertical gradients of the carbon tracers increased significantly.
